description: What is a class in Java?

alternatives.text: An object created in memory during program execution
A blueprint that defines the attributes and behaviors of objects
A special method that initializes variables
A collection of independent functions

explanation: A class is a blueprint that defines the attributes (data) and methods (behaviors) that objects created from it will have.

description: How do you create an instance (object) of a class called 'Car' in Java?

alternatives.text: Car myCar = Car();
Car myCar = create Car();
Car myCar = new Car();
new Car myCar = Car();

explanation: To create an object in Java, use the 'new' keyword followed by the class name and parentheses: new Car(). This calls the class constructor.

description: What is a constructor in Java?

alternatives.text: A method that returns an object of the class type
A special method with the same name as the class, no return type, used to initialize objects
A variable that stores the initial state of the class
A block of code executed when the class is removed from memory

explanation: A constructor is a special method with the same name as the class and no return type (not even void). It is called automatically when an object is created with 'new'.

description: What is the difference between a field and a method in a class?

alternatives.text: Fields are public and methods are private
There is no difference; they are the same thing
Fields represent data (state) and methods represent behaviors (actions)
Methods store data and fields execute logic

explanation: Fields (attributes) hold the state of an object, such as name or age. Methods define what the object can do, such as calculating or displaying information.

description: What happens when you use the 'new' keyword to create an object?

alternatives.text: The class code is erased from memory
The compiler checks for syntax errors
New memory is allocated and the class constructor is called
The class is copied and renamed

explanation: The 'new' keyword allocates memory for the new object and calls the class constructor to initialize it. The object then exists in heap memory.

description: What is the main purpose of the 'return' keyword in Java?

alternatives.text: To terminate the program
To end a method's execution and optionally send a value back to the caller
To declare the return type of a method
To repeat a method's execution

explanation: 'return' immediately ends the method's execution and sends a value (if the method is not void) back to the caller. No line after 'return' will execute.

description: What happens to code written after a 'return' statement inside a method?

alternatives.text: It executes normally after the return
It causes a compilation error if it is unreachable
It is silently ignored
It only executes if the returned value is null

explanation: The Java compiler detects unreachable code after a 'return' statement and generates a compilation error. Code after 'return' will never execute.

description: A method declared as 'int calculate()' must:

alternatives.text: Use 'return void' at the end
Return an int value on every possible execution path
Have no return statement
Return a String value

explanation: When a method declares a return type (such as int), every possible execution path must have a 'return' statement with a value compatible with that type.

description: Can a method have more than one 'return' statement?

alternatives.text: No, there can only be one return per method
Yes, but only in void methods
Yes, in different conditions (like inside if/else), but only one will execute per call
Yes, and all of them will execute in sequence

explanation: A method can have multiple 'return' statements, usually in conditional branches. However, reaching any 'return' ends the method — only one executes per call.

description: Which of the following is a CORRECT use of 'return' in a method that returns int?

alternatives.text: return "ten";
return 10;
return true;
return;

explanation: The value after 'return' must be compatible with the declared return type. If the method returns 'int', the returned value must be an integer, such as 10.

description: What does declaring a method as 'void' mean in Java?

alternatives.text: The method returns zero
The method does not return any value
The method is private and cannot be accessed
The method can return any type of value

explanation: 'void' indicates that the method performs an action but does not return any data to the caller. Use it when the method's purpose is to produce an effect, not compute a value.

description: Can a 'void' method contain a 'return' statement?

alternatives.text: No, that would cause a compilation error
Yes, but only 'return;' with no value, to exit the method early
Yes, and it must return null
Yes, and it can return any value

explanation: Void methods can use 'return;' (without a value) to exit early. Returning a value in a void method causes a compilation error.

description: When is it appropriate to use 'void' instead of a return type like 'int' or 'String'?

alternatives.text: When the method is very complex
When the method performs an action (e.g., display, save, send) without needing to return a result
When the method returns more than one value
When the method is a constructor

explanation: Use 'void' when the method performs an action whose result doesn't need to be returned. Examples: printing to the screen, saving to a file, sending data to another system.

description: What happens when you call a 'void' method in an assignment expression like: int x = myMethod();

alternatives.text: x receives the value 0
x receives null
Compilation error, because void cannot be assigned to a variable
It works normally, but x is empty

explanation: Void methods return no value, so they cannot be used in assignment expressions. The compiler will throw an error because there is nothing to assign to the variable.

description: Which of the following is a correct void method?

alternatives.text: void display() { return "Hello"; }
void display() { System.out.println("Hello"); }
int display() { System.out.println("Hello"); }
void display() { return 0; }

explanation: A void method must perform actions without returning a value. System.out.println is a perfect example: it displays something on screen but returns nothing to the caller.

description: What are the four pillars of Object-Oriented Programming (OOP)?

alternatives.text: Compilation, Execution, Debugging and Testing
Encapsulation, Inheritance, Polymorphism and Abstraction
Classes, Objects, Methods and Attributes
Variables, Loops, Conditions and Functions

explanation: The four pillars of OOP are: Encapsulation (protecting data), Inheritance (reusing code), Polymorphism (multiple forms), and Abstraction (hiding complexity).

description: What is encapsulation in OOP?

alternatives.text: The ability of a class to inherit from another
The practice of hiding an object's internal data, controlling access through methods
Creating multiple objects from a class
The ability of a method to call itself

explanation: Encapsulation is the principle of protecting an object's data by making fields private and exposing public methods (getters/setters) for controlled access.

description: What is an object in OOP?

alternatives.text: The same thing as a class
A concrete instance of a class, with its own state and behavior
A method with no parameters
A Java source file

explanation: An object is a concrete instance of a class. While the class is the blueprint, the object is the 'real thing' created from it, with its own attribute values.

description: In Java, which keyword is used for a class to inherit from another?

alternatives.text: implements
inherits
extends
super

explanation: The 'extends' keyword is used for inheritance in Java: class Dog extends Animal {}. This allows Dog to inherit fields and methods from the Animal class.

description: What is abstraction in OOP?

alternatives.text: Hiding the source code from the developer
Creating objects without using classes
Exposing only the essential features of an object, hiding implementation details
Converting one data type to another

explanation: Abstraction means showing only what is necessary and hiding internal complexity. For example, when you use System.out.println(), you don't need to know how it works internally.

description: What does the CIA Triad stand for in cybersecurity?

alternatives.text: Cyber, Intelligence, Antivirus
Confidentiality, Integrity, Availability
Control, Identification, Access
Compliance, Isolation, Authentication

explanation: The CIA Triad is the foundational model of information security: Confidentiality (only authorized users can access data), Integrity (data is accurate and unaltered), and Availability (systems are accessible when needed).

description: What is the difference between authentication and authorization?

alternatives.text: They are the same thing
Authentication verifies who you are; authorization determines what you can do
Authorization verifies who you are; authentication determines what you can do
Authentication only applies to passwords; authorization applies to all credentials

explanation: Authentication answers 'Who are you?' (e.g., logging in with a password). Authorization answers 'What are you allowed to do?' (e.g., can you read this file or access this endpoint).

description: What is malware?

alternatives.text: A type of hardware device used to intercept network traffic
Any software intentionally designed to cause damage, steal data, or disrupt systems
A security tool that monitors network activity
An outdated or poorly written software program

explanation: Malware (malicious software) is any program designed to harm, exploit, or otherwise compromise systems or data. It includes viruses, worms, trojans, ransomware, spyware, and more.

description: A piece of malware that encrypts a victim's files and demands payment to restore access is called:

alternatives.text: A worm
Spyware
Ransomware
A trojan

explanation: Ransomware encrypts the victim's files or locks their system and demands a ransom (usually in cryptocurrency) for the decryption key. Notable examples include WannaCry and LockBit.

description: What is a phishing attack?

alternatives.text: An attack that floods a server with traffic until it crashes
A technique where attackers impersonate trusted entities to trick users into revealing sensitive information
A method of intercepting encrypted network traffic
An exploit that targets vulnerabilities in web browsers

explanation: Phishing attackers pose as legitimate organizations (banks, tech companies, colleagues) via email, SMS, or fake websites to steal credentials, financial data, or install malware.

description: What is social engineering in a cybersecurity context?

alternatives.text: Using algorithms to analyze social media data
Manipulating people psychologically to perform actions or divulge confidential information
Building secure software through team collaboration
Engineering firewalls to block social media platforms

explanation: Social engineering exploits human psychology rather than technical vulnerabilities. Attackers build trust, create urgency, or impersonate authority figures to bypass security controls — humans are often the weakest link.

description: What is the key difference between symmetric and asymmetric encryption?

alternatives.text: Symmetric is faster but uses two different keys; asymmetric uses one key
Symmetric uses one shared key for both encryption and decryption; asymmetric uses a key pair (public/private)
Symmetric is used for data at rest; asymmetric is only for passwords
There is no practical difference — both use the same number of keys

explanation: Symmetric encryption (e.g., AES) uses the same key to encrypt and decrypt — fast but the key must be shared securely. Asymmetric encryption (e.g., RSA) uses a public key to encrypt and a private key to decrypt, enabling secure key exchange.

description: What is hashing, and how does it differ from encryption?

alternatives.text: Hashing is reversible; encryption is not
Hashing produces a fixed-length digest that cannot be reversed; encryption can be decrypted with the right key
They are the same — both use keys to transform data
Hashing is only used for network packets; encryption is for files

explanation: Hashing (e.g., SHA-256, bcrypt) is a one-way function — you cannot recover the original input from the hash. It's used for password storage and data integrity checks. Encryption is two-way — data can be decrypted with the correct key.

description: What is the primary function of a firewall?

alternatives.text: To encrypt all network traffic automatically
To monitor and control incoming and outgoing network traffic based on security rules
To scan files for malware before they are downloaded
To assign IP addresses to devices on a network

explanation: A firewall acts as a gatekeeper between networks, allowing or blocking traffic based on predefined rules. It can be hardware-based, software-based, or both, and is a fundamental layer of network defense.

description: What does HTTPS provide over plain HTTP?

alternatives.text: Faster page load times through compression
Encrypted communication between the browser and server, ensuring confidentiality and integrity
Automatic authentication of the user
Protection against all types of web application attacks

explanation: HTTPS uses TLS (Transport Layer Security) to encrypt the connection between client and server, preventing eavesdropping and tampering. It also authenticates the server via digital certificates.

description: What is Multi-Factor Authentication (MFA)?

alternatives.text: Using multiple passwords for the same account
A security mechanism requiring two or more verification factors from different categories to grant access
Logging in from multiple devices simultaneously
A type of encryption that uses multiple keys

explanation: MFA requires something you know (password), something you have (phone/token), and/or something you are (biometric). Even if a password is stolen, an attacker cannot log in without the second factor.

description: What is the Principle of Least Privilege?

alternatives.text: Giving all users administrator access to avoid support requests
Granting users and systems only the minimum permissions necessary to perform their function
Restricting all users from accessing any sensitive data
Applying the lowest encryption standard that still meets compliance requirements

explanation: The Principle of Least Privilege (PoLP) minimizes risk by limiting access rights. A compromised account or misconfigured service can only do as much damage as its permissions allow — reducing the blast radius of an attack.

description: What is a SQL Injection attack?

alternatives.text: An attack that corrupts a database's physical storage
An attack where malicious SQL code is inserted into an input field to manipulate the database
An attack that overwhelms a database server with requests
An attack targeting the SQL server's operating system

explanation: SQL injection occurs when user input is not properly sanitized and malicious SQL code is injected into queries. This can expose, modify, or delete data. Prevention: use parameterized queries / prepared statements.

matter.content:
-- Vulnerable query:
SELECT * FROM users WHERE username = '" + input + "'

-- Attack input:
' OR '1'='1

-- Resulting query (returns ALL users):
SELECT * FROM users WHERE username = '' OR '1'='1'

description: What is a Man-in-the-Middle (MITM) attack?

alternatives.text: An attack where the attacker sits between two communicating parties, intercepting and possibly altering their messages
An attack where the attacker impersonates an administrator
An attack that targets the middleware layer of an application
An attack that floods a network switch with MAC addresses

explanation: In a MITM attack, the attacker secretly intercepts communication between two parties who believe they are communicating directly. This can allow credential theft, session hijacking, or data manipulation. HTTPS and certificate pinning help prevent it.

description: What is a DDoS attack?

alternatives.text: An attack that steals data by decrypting network packets
An attack that uses many compromised systems to overwhelm a target with traffic, making it unavailable
An attack that deletes data from a distributed database
An attack that installs malware on multiple devices simultaneously

explanation: A Distributed Denial of Service (DDoS) attack floods a target (website, server, network) with traffic from many sources (often a botnet) to exhaust its resources and make it unavailable to legitimate users — attacking the Availability pillar of the CIA Triad.

description: What is a zero-day vulnerability?

alternatives.text: A vulnerability that has been patched within zero days of discovery
A flaw in software that is unknown to the vendor and has no available patch
A vulnerability that only affects systems with zero security controls
A new vulnerability introduced when code is deployed at midnight

explanation: A zero-day vulnerability is a software flaw that is unknown to the developer or vendor — they have had 'zero days' to fix it. Attackers who discover zero-days have a significant advantage since no patch exists yet.

description: Which of the following is considered the BEST practice for creating strong passwords?

alternatives.text: Using a short word with numbers substituting letters, like 'p4ssw0rd'
Reusing the same complex password across all accounts for consistency
Using long, random, unique passphrases or passwords managed by a password manager
Changing your password every 30 days while keeping a similar structure

explanation: Length and uniqueness matter most. Long random passphrases are harder to crack than short complex passwords. A password manager generates and stores unique credentials per account, eliminating reuse — the most dangerous password habit.

description: What does 'defense in depth' mean in cybersecurity?

alternatives.text: Using the most advanced firewall available as the sole security measure
Applying multiple, overlapping layers of security controls so that if one fails, others still protect the system
Keeping all security configurations secret from developers
Focusing all security resources on protecting the network perimeter

explanation: Defense in depth is a layered security strategy: firewalls, intrusion detection, encryption, access controls, security training, and monitoring all work together. No single control is sufficient; redundancy creates resilience.

description: What is the purpose of a VPN (Virtual Private Network)?

alternatives.text: To make your internet connection faster
To create an encrypted tunnel for your traffic, masking your IP and protecting data in transit
To permanently delete files so they cannot be recovered
To scan your device for malware in real time

explanation: A VPN encrypts your internet traffic and routes it through a server, hiding your IP address and protecting your data from eavesdroppers — especially important on untrusted public Wi-Fi. For organizations, VPNs also provide secure remote access to internal networks.

description: Why is it important to keep software and operating systems up to date?

alternatives.text: Updates improve the user interface but have no impact on security
Updates often include patches for known vulnerabilities that attackers actively exploit
Outdated software is generally more stable and secure than newer versions
Software updates are only necessary for antivirus programs

explanation: Unpatched software is one of the most common attack vectors. When a vulnerability is disclosed, attackers race to exploit systems that haven't yet applied the patch. Regular updates are one of the simplest and most effective security measures.
